key_title: Key to the genera of Asparagaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the families in the Asparagales-Liliales complex

leads.lead_text: Ovary inferior or half-inferior; leaves basal, massive, fleshy, up to 2 m long or more, with marginal and terminal spines; inflorescence a panicle on a stout, fleshy scape 3–6 m high
Plants lacking the above combination of characters
[link through]
Inflorescence an umbel
Inflorescence otherwise or flowers solitary
Leaves herbaceous, basal; flowers on scapes mostly 30 cm high or more; stamens 3;  stems lacking aerial stilt-roots
Leaves rigid, somewhat pungent, borne on branching stems; flowers sessile or on scapes mostly less than 30 cm high; stamens 6; stems often stilt-rooted
[link through]
Rootstock a bulb or corm
Rootstock otherwise
Tepals fused for c. half their length or more
Tepals free or shortly fused at the base
Flowers blue or mauve {rarely white}; perianth deciduous
Flowers white {sometimes with green medial stripe}, yellow, or red; perianth persisting in fruit
Inflorescence racemose, usually secund; flowers often pendulous, subtended by 2 membranous bracts; petals fused at base
Inflorescence in a raceme or corymb, or flowers solitary; flowers usually pendent or erect, subtended by a membranous bract or ebracteate; petals free
[link through]
Bulb to 35 mm diameter; leaves 1 or 2; tepals red or yellow
Bulb to 10 cm diameter; leaves many; tepals white {sometimes with green medial stripe}
Tepals thick-textured, ± oblong, white or yellow with a distinct green or brown stipe associated with a network of 3–5 veins
Tepals thick- or thin-textured, ovate or lanceolate, unicoloured or with a narrow green or brown stripe not associated with a network of nerves
Plants dioecious, male and female inflorescences usually markedly dissimilar; leaves basal, harsh-textured, isolateral, usually exceeding inflorescence
Flowers bisexual, or if ever dioecious, male and female inflorescences similar; leaves not as above
Stamens bearded
Stamens without hairs, filaments rarely sparsely puberulent

Leaves reduced to scale-like bracts subtending filiform or ovate, leaf-like cladodes; flowers small, unisexual, pale, solitary or paired, on decurved pedicels; fruit a red or black berry; plants escaped from cultivation
Cladodes absent; leaves not scale-like; if fruit berry-like, then inflorescence a raceme, cyme or panicle
Erect to arching rhizomatous herbs; stems unbranched; inflorescence axillary, in raceme-like clusters; perianth fused into tube
Perianth free or shortly united basally, if fused into tube, then inflorescence a terminal raceme and otherwise not as above
[link through]
Scandent vines or sub-shrubs of eastern rainforests and moist lowland forests; fruit a fleshy capsule
Not as above
[link through]
Plant developing a woody trunk, often several metres tall; inflorescence a panicle; garden-escaped
Plant, if ever with trunk, not or hardly woody; inflorescence racemose
Perianth spreading, up to 1 cm long (Victoria only); leaves harsh-textured, tufted at ends of branches, apex not spine-tipped
Perianth campanulate, 4–5 cm long (Victoria only); leaves tufted at ends of branches or basal, often sheading elongate fibres at margin, apex usually spine-tipped
[link through]
Petals with fringed margins, broader than sepals
Petals with entire margins, equal or subequal to sepals
[link through]
